number of helpful: 290 of 307 people (94%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
r 13, 2014
												First off, do not go into Clear Sky if you haven't at least played Shadow of Chernobyl first. I'll begin with my overall opinion of CS. It's inferior compared to SoC, and especially inferior compared to CoP. The Faction Wars system, one of the main selling points to CS, is confusing at best. You can side with three different factions in each area of the game (though you automatically side with one by default at the beginning), and then certain factions become hostile towards you. In return, you get the chance to earn extra jobs and top-tier equipment earlier than normal. The only problem is when you have to actually fight the opposing factions. You need to travel to certain areas of the map, take out any resistance you encounter there, and wait for backup to arrive. In addition, if any of those areas come under attack, you're expected to show up and help out. Thus, you sometimes wind up with scenarios where you're halfway across the map, and get a call from a lone survivor armed with a shotgun to high-tail it over to their position and kindly take out the group of seven guys all armed with military-grade automatic rifles, please. The worst part is that your opposing factions don't stay dead. I've captured every single point including the main base, and killed everyone I possibly could, and they just respawn the second you leave. The good news is, while you will still have to help your allies out, you still get paid a substantial amount of cash for taking out the main base, so it's not all bad, I suppose.Without a doubt, the worst part of CS is the enemy AI. For the most part, it's the same as SoC, except for the fact that these enemies can use grenades. Even on lower difficulties, you'll be tapping the quicksave button every few kills just in case they decide to spontaneously send an entire squads' worth of grenades next to your feet. Even worse is the fact that the AI is ungodly accurate with those grenades. Wherever they throw them, they end up directly at your feet with a one-second fuse. It's not at all uncommon to watch an enemy throw a grenade in the wrong direction (as in, they're facing away from you), only to see it reverse directions in mid-air and teleport right next to you. This is especially bad on the final mission, where enemies literally spawn from nowhere armed with automatics loaded with armor-piercing rounds and grenades primed and ready. The most common thing I found myself looking for in CS was not ammo, or artifacts, or even money, as opposed to SoC. No, it was bandages and medkits to replenish any health I was losing from unfair grenades. If you're playing through on higher difficulties, your first priority is to find some armor that isn't completely terrible, and then stock up on as many healing items as you can. Otherwise, you most likely won't stand a chance.If you're coming from SoC, you should know that the system for picking up artifacts is radically different than how it used to be. Where they used to be waiting on the ground in plain sight for you to just grab, they're now hidden in the centers of anomalies. You won't be able to grab an artifact unless you have your detector out (press the O button to pull the detector out, and press 2 to dual-weild it with your pistol), and unless the anomaly you're looking at happens to contain one. Most anomalies don't. Personally, I held off on artifact hunting until I got a better detector, but if you can deal with lots of trial-and-error and quicksaving, you're welcome to try.Speaking of artifacts, not every piece of armor you find can actually equip them. For some, you need to take it to a person who can upgrade weapons and armor, and pray that they're capable of adding an artifact container or two. Thankfully, most armors can, although it will cost you a good amount of money, even more than upgrading a top-tier assault rifle. Speaking of upgrades, if you couldn't already tell, you can do that now. The same people who offer upgrades also repair your damaged weapons and armor (for a nominal fee, of course), sell you locations of stashes (which can also be found on dead bodies, although sometimes the person selling you a location will tell you what you can find before you open it), and offer you jobs which usually consist of "find information on a particular upgrade in a stash somewhere and bring it back to me". Keep in mind that you still need to find the stash first, as it's not marked on your map.CS has a much different atmosphere compared to SoC and even CoP. While the other two are generally dark and dreary, Clear Sky is actually rather nice. By comparison, I mean. It's still the Zone, after all. It feels a bit out-of-place compared to the other two, but given that this is a prequel and things aren't as bad yet, it's to be expected. The mutants are still there, so it's not too different, but it is certainly noticeable.All that being said, I still think Clear Sky is a fun game. If you can deal with the grenades, the different atmosphere, and the gameplay changes from SoC, you shouldn't have any problems at all with it. Be warned that it is a STALKER game, and is prone to bugs and crashes. I got lucky and only had two with this one, as opposed to CoP which wouldn't launch for the longest time, and SoC which crashed several times and wouldn't let me begin a new game without freezing until I messed with the options. If these happen to you, the very first things you should try are running Steam as administrator, disabling the Steam overlay while in-game, and switching the lighting options to Static. Those will solve a large amount of the issues you'll encounter.

												After 6 years people still think Chernobyl is in Russia 10/10EDIT Since people actually voted this review to go to the top I will write a normal review to it below !This game is set in chernobyl few years after the incident. Because of the radiation a lot of weird things happen , anomalies , mutated animals and other monsters and the most important thing , the artefacts which are small valuable objects made from the anomalies. You are a STALKER , a person who came to the "Zone" (area around chernobyll) to risk your life and get those valuable artefacts. In this game you will do a lot of things , make missions , fight people , fight animals etcThis game doesn't have any PRG mechanics but It doesn't need them , you have a whole map to exlpore , do mission and collect artefacts which you can then sell and upgrade your gear of buy new things.A new thing that was added was fraction system where you can choose a fraction and you can fight other factions , although that sounds really good I don't like the way it was made because even if you clear out a map of enemy troops and you leave the area 10 min later you will get a notification that an outpost is under attack even doe you cleared out the whole area which I personally hate!They also added a new feature which I really like which is upgrading your gear so now money is actually really useful not like in SOC where after some time money was basiclly useless but now you need a lot of money and I found that it's way harder to get the money as well To people who are returning form SOC there are few diffrences in this game like for example collecting artefacts which you can't see them no more , now you have to take out your artefact detector and come close to an anomaly and pray that there is one in there which personaly I don't like that system because artefacts are now super rare and It's rare that you actually get one that you can use for yourself.I reccomend this game to everyone! 10/10

content:
24, 2015
Immersive & unsettling // Recommended for horror-survival enthusiasts looking for a challenge*As I am reviewing the core product, and not various third-party mods, this review is based on a purely vanilla playthrough. Please keep that in mind, thank you!+ Many locations and characters from Shadow of Chernobyl make a reappearance in this title+ Equipment and weight limitations do much to force the optimization of one's gear, and make one choose what to discard and what to keep; this leaves the player feeling both challenged and rewarded as they acclimate to the concept+ Artifacts add slight RPG-like stat combinations; these are more challenging to use than in the previous installment, though many will enjoy the increase in challenge+ Very, very strong sense of atmosphere pervading throughout+ Boasts a large and active modding community (many mods do well to address some of the game's various pitfalls)+ Ambient sounds are absolutely fantastic, and keep the player consistently unsettled+ Manner of interaction with various game-world NPCs is largely determined by the player's actions throughout the adventure; can join and help differing factions, netting different rewards (friendly factions will even show up occasionally if you're in a firefight, and they will aid you)+ The game's world and atmosphere complements an intriguing plot; the story, itself, rewards inquisitiveness+ Absolute plethora of side-missions+ The game's environments are vast and very detailed; visuals, too, are crisp and the lighting mechanics excellent+ Fast travel is included (for a fee, unfortunately)+ Finding artifacts, as compared to the game's predecessor, is a new and unique challenge- Lip syncronization is absolutely atrocious- Hunger and thirst has been removed; some may view this as a positive, but as this series tends to attract the purists in the RPG community, most would likely see this as a negative- Bullet mechanics can often be questionable in behavior- Crouching, much like in the first installment, is laughable; one's character lowers by perhaps an inch, and it offers virtually no protection in any given situationLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
28, 2015
												Head back into The Zone, taking on bandits and the military as you explore the environments from the first game. Sounds fun enough?Well, the enjoyment you get from STALKER games is dependent on whether or not you're able to overlook and put up with all manner of errors, bugs and little idiosyncracies. I'm talking enemies with pistols turned into sniper rifles, a lack of healing items and grenades that land right at your feet from hundreds of feet away. These are amazingly atmospheric games and the worlds they have are so believable and well crafted it's just a shame that they quite often don't function the way they're supposed to.Clear Sky is the black sheep of the series and by that I mean it's the game that most people agree is the weakest of the three. I still give this one a thumbs up because there really is nothing else like it and it is worth playing the entire trilogy if you're into them at all.But this is still a deeply flawed game and you might want to check out some mods to get it running smoothly and make it a bit more forgiving.Full video review:

content:
, 2014
												Catching up on my PC video gaming has been something of a spiritual journey for me. I have found my highs, my lows and then there has been a special place that doesn’t quite measure on the spectrum. S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Clear Sky seems to take that measurement system and throw it out the 10th storey window. I want to put it somewhere on the bar with the likes of Half-Life 2, but then no, it doesn’t quite add up. Whilst the game mechanics are very similar at times, I find myself comparing it more to Metro:2033… then again it often feels more like Fallout 3. There’s no denying it has similarities but doesn’t quite match any of them individually. The game has found a very small pocket within the genre to carve out its own place in game history as a deftly challenging, gritty & unique game. It combines elements of successful titles and throws them all together creating something new, inspiring, very challenging & brutal. It is proof of truly evolved gaming that was made by gamers who have a great understanding of games & have refined it in a very Russian way. Cold, calculative & ultimately, brilliant.

ry 8, 2014
												Good game, I can see why some people hate it though. Since faction quests in this game just mess up the game. I sided with Freedom, and I had to deal with bandits/duty etc making the game 10X more difficult than it should have been. Also there is a main quest area where bandits take your stuff.. you get them back, but NOT the money! I lost a ton of cash with that, since I was stockpiling it. Best to go through that part first before farming, and DO NOT join ANY faction. Unless you like a good "challenge". The length is about the same as SoC and longer than CoP, and, in my opinion, bigger than CoP since the zones are smaller and more numerous. Way more side quests in CS due to more areas, much like the original SoC, weapon upgrade system (another bad part of joining a faction, it limits your upgrades) revamped artifact finding, better inventory facelift, graphical improvements, etc. I DO intend on replaying this one as well since I will not make the mistake of joining a faction. :P So this review is more of a reminder to myself than anything else. :D

content:
28, 2015
												"Clear Sky" is brutal, uncompromising, and definitely worth a try.I remember becoming pretty decent at "Shadow Of Chernobyl." Maybe I had the difficulty pulled back a bit for that game. I can't quite remember.Even so, I don't remember "Shadow" being as downright mean as "Clear Sky" feels.You will die. A lot. Continuously. I'm not really exaggerating when I say you should consider saving after anything whatsoever goes in your favor. Clear a group of attackers? Save. Take down a single hostile? Save. Walk forward for 30 seconds without getting irradiated, falling into an anomaly, chewed up by dogs, or shot? Save. Stand still for a few moments without anything bad happening? Save. Hear anything even mildly "story-based" in a conversation? Save. Just successfully saved a game? Save again.Seriously, I was more adept at hitting F5 than the default run-toggle key after only a short time.And be aware that it's possible (though unlikely) to save a game that won't completely reload. The engine will get to the "Synchronizing" stage and then hang.Save multiple saves at multiple times.Oh, and you think you're pretty good with guns in videogames? Yeah - about that. In Clear Sky, here's how it works: Your enemies, even the dirt-poor bandits, fire munitions that can apparently home in on you in the dark from across the map. This behavior extends to individual shotgun pellets. Also, their grenades are seemingly possessed of a malevolent intelligence that WILL find you. Through walls. In the dark.Now, for your part, any weapon that is not a sniper rifle fired from the prone position has about an 80% chance of MISSING whatever it is you're trying to kill. You will fire entire magazines - and I'm talking about one shot at a time, not full-auto - and every bullet but one will guide itself to a point that is not the thing in your crosshairs. If you do hit something by micraculous happenstance, you will have to hit it many MANY times before it drops. This applies to the aforementioned bandits, and the well-equipped military. (It's just that the military kills you faster and takes twice the lead before they drop.) With the notable exception of the Bloodsuckers, any hostile you encounter can be expected to behave as though they were made of solid steel and wearing armor of similarly solid steel.You, of course, are made of wet tissue-paper. Some decent armor will upgrade you to dry cardboard. The thin kind, I mean. Not the cool stuff that they make shipping boxes with.Oh, and ammunition is pretty scarce. Also expensive. And the stuff you scrounge and sell to the traders? They buy it cheap. Some things they won't even pay you for. What they sell to you, naturally, carries a hefty premium. You can eventually build a stockpile of essentials, but it will take a while. It will also take a while because the fast-travel system (the guides) costs money to use, and you need to save that money for bullets. A trip to a trader that has anything worth buying often requires walking across nearly the whole world.Getting rewards for completed missions also follows that formula. That squad-leader you just risked life and limb for? No, he doesn't have the money with him. You have to walk all the way back to The Cordon for that measly 750 RU. No, he doesn't want to buy anything you have on you, except food and vodka. Have a nice trip! Hope you don't get ambushed on the way!And you should definitely build that ammo stockpile. As soon as you commit to a certain kind of weapon, you will go up against a horde of enemies that are carrying weapons chambered for whatever you DON'T prefer. It's almost uncanny.Also, before getting rolled up into the endgame, make sure you have all the best gear that exists in the world. Otherwise, you will be like me. You'll get all the way to Chernobyl, and then the game will become effectively unwinnable because you're up against nearly invincible enemies that warp in and can magically shoot around cover. You will need lots of bandages - as in, every single one you can find, and probably ten more. Plus every medkit you can get your hands on, and the best armor in the game. All that, and 1000 rounds of AR ammo. And every bullet you can possibly get for two different sniper rifles. You might have a chance.All of the above sounds terrifying and awful, but I also have to say something else: "Clear Sky" is oddly compelling. It took me almost 27 hours of getting abused by the game before I finally decided that I didn't care. Up to that point, I was thoroughly engrossed. The bleak, strange, and unsettling environment is intriguing, and the overall challenge somehow manages to make you want to try again (most of the time). Oh, and when the game decides to mess with your mind, it REALLY succeeds.So, give "Clear Sky" a shot. Several shots, actually. Like I said, good luck with actually HITTING anything.Geeze.

content:
r 30, 2014
												(**EDIT** I just finished the game, and lemme say, if you haven't played the first game, the ending will not make sense. Even if you have played the first game, the ending is not very satisfying. In my opinion, you should get your enjoyment out of the rest of the game, because there isn't much to be found at the end.)Rough, somewhat broken, but with a little love is simply fantastic. It's atmosphere is unmatched, it draws you in like your character's body draws in radiation. Also, the voice acting is meh, but that's part of why we love STALKER.Vanilla, the game has many glitches, ugly models and textures, super accurate and powerful enemies, innacurate and weak player weaponry, and questionable design decisions, but mods and a bit of technical know-how can turn this game into something beautiful. Well, maybe it's not visually beautiful how I run it, but I enjoyed it thoroughly nonetheless. I personally can recommend Clear Sky Complete mod, as well as The Road to Limansk. You can find both of those mods on the ModDB page for Clear Sky (Road to Limank says that it hasnt released yet; it has, just follow the links on the page).Also, you should get STALKER: Lost Alpha, a free fan remake of Shadow of Chernobyl, with loads of lore-friendly added content. I never played SoC, so I can't compare the two, but hey, it's free. Also, be sure to get Boredgunner's Lost Alpha Mod Pack 2014, which updates all weapon models, animations and sounds, adds 50-ish new weapons, and tweaks the economy to be more fair in terms of pricing and item availability (among other things... check out his ModDB page at http://www.moddb.com/games/stalker/downloads/lost-alpha-mod-pack-2014) . I am having a blast playing Lost Alpha, and you should be playing it too!

content:
6, 2014
												I'm just going to stress that Clear Sky isn't as good as Shadow of Chernobyl or Call of Pripyat. It has numerous problems. Not the least of which is just a lack of focus. It recycles half of Shadow of Chernobyl's maps and has a less interesting story to boot.However, bearing all that in mind it is priced 10$ cheaper and features a rather unique "faction war" mechanic. This mechanic essentially has it so that all the different factions in the Zone do battle with each other in real time. The player can join a faction if they so desire, and doing so gives them ready access to better equipment and more friendly areas in the Zone. All in the hopes of taking over the Zone through pure conquest.The faction war mechanic is extremely well done in this game, and is the reason why anyone plays Clear Sky to this day. Whether it is worth getting is really up to you, since it is the awkward middle child in the series.

content:
, 2016
												A story from when I had a non-Steam copy of the game, that I posted as a comment in a thread back in 2013:"I do have one specific memory of Clear Sky being creepy.I was wandering around in the Red Forest, minding my own business. I noticed it was getting close to night, so I made my way to the group of Duty guys at the edge of the forest. When I got there, there were 2 of them dead, and one bleeding out on the ground.I heard dogs, and saw them dragging one of the dead bodies back into the forest. Then, I heard a bloodsucker woosh from behind, and immediately ran to the guy bleeding out, healed him, and we tried to fight together.That didn't last long as he got killed by the bloodsucker just 5 seconds after I healed him. I ran to the building, went up the stairs, basically cornered myself to the wall, got out my shotgun, and waited until morning. Every now and then, I would think the bloodsucker was gone, try to leave, only to hear that grunting/snorting sound and a woosh again, reminding me to stay put.Eventually, it was morning, a lone Duty guy came back to take the building over again and it was over.Remember, this was all while it was pitch black out at night and before I even knew what a bloodsucker was."Edit: changed "the" to "that"

content:
, 2016
Pros-Absolutely amazing atmosphere and sceneries.-Very immersive and realistic game.-Great gameplay, lots of guns, armors and artefacts.-Interesting story, deep lore and funny dialogues.-Very hard but insanely satisfying to complete missions.-Huge replayability with Faction Wars, side quests and hidden loots.-Stalkers will always be ready to share a campfire with you and play you relaxed songs on their guitar, no matter that you're in the Zone and could be seconds away from an emission or a mutant attack.-Great sound effects.-Cheeki Breeki.-Good music, proof: 


YouTube™ Video: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky - Bandit Radio 

			Views: 1,536,449		



Cons-Lots of bugs (not to the point where it's unplayable, you just have to save really often and optimally make multiple save files).-Unsatisfying ending.-Enemies will always throw their grenades perfectly at you, it's unreal.Brief descriptionTchernobyl has spoken. The world around you, called the Zone, is now an apocalyptic wasteland, where some Stalkers, survivors of the disaster, have organized in groups to fight for their lives against the wilderness and against each other. But someone went too far up the center of the Zone, and the Zone is not happy. It's reacting by releasing deadly emissions who make no survivors, or almost none. But you have someting special, and you survived the onslaught of the Zone. Your quest, Mercenary Scar, is to reach the center of the Zone and find out how to calm this monstrous ecosystem that is making life on earth hell. Your quest will not be easy, as creepy mutants, zombies, bandits and emissions will try to stand in your way in this first person shooting/survival game. Good luck.Personal opinionI will always have many fond memories of this game, and it will always stay as one of my favorite games of all time. For so many reasons... The graphics, the gameplay, the dialogues, it all just feels like you really are some guy trying to survive in a fearsome world. It all feels so good when you finally succeed in what you are doing. You feel good. You feel good because the game doesn't help you. The game doesn't give you any chances. Hence, when you finally manage to fend off countless waves of mutants or assault a military outpost, you feel like you did it all by yourself, against all odds.VerdictI definitely, absolutely and unquestionnably recommend this game. I loved every part of it, and think you will too. And it's really cheap. 100% worth it.

content:
er 26, 2015
												Now, Part 2 of the revisions. To recap after the 1st stalker game revision....this is based on the vanilla experience.Ah, the prequel. Also, the game that the stalker community thought was forgettable. Me? I personally LOVED this game. Sure, it's missing a few things....namely hunger, and an all-around creepiness with some of the environments. But to counter, this game introduced some features that proved to be worthwhile; for instance, the weapon and armor upgrades and repair. Do the weapons and armor still degrade? Yes, but now you can enhance them with more armor plates, flex the durability, and even add protection against anomalies. It's needed because if you ask me, this is the hardest of the 3 stalker games. Just as is with the first game, once you get to a certain point, there's no turning back. So, be prepared for ANY situation again. The story revolves around Scar, a mercenary that inserts himself into the faction war. Various factions are battling for territory in the zone in a race to reach the center. When a group of stalkers reaches the center, the zone changes and becomes more unstable, making the territory more valuable. Gameplay is relatively the same with a few changes. First, the artifacts aren't just there for the taking this time. You need a detector to find the artifacts, which involves getting into the thick of the anomaly. The weakest detectors won't spot the best artifacts, so you need a top notch one to make up for the weaker ones shortcomings. This game also manages to feel less like a sandbox, only because as you progress through the story you are able to uncover more of the map. In other words, you're actually blocked from progressing far into the zone until you progress through the story. Once you get so far, then it's open for you to explore all over. Numerous players weren't fond of this because of the open nature of the 1st game, but i think it worked well here because it made for better pacing. You couldn't get the best weapon in the game very early, giving you a major advantage. Even the armor suits were paced better, as an exoskeleton suit COULD be given to you about half way through, but required some work on your part in joining the faction wars for Duty or Freedom. Better pacing equals more fun if you ask me. The stalker way is the hard way.Artifacts were not so abundant here, as each map in the zone contained a few anomalies, which hold artifacts. With less artifacts comes less money, which means upgrading or repairing was a little tricky because you had to draw the line between keeping an artifact or trading it in for a valuable upgrade. Less money also equals more fun. Stalker games are supposed to be challenging and this adds another layer of challenge. Of course, once you get so far and have your armor or weapons upgraded, then you can save some money for future use. The AI has some improvements, but still has its pros and cons. The faction wars can be a bit buggy sometimes, as the AI isn't entirely supportive. You may find yourself doing alot of the work, and while this game is difficult as it is, i personally don't mind doing most of the work. It's a shooter.....you shoot things. The more the merrier. Most of the maps are reused from Shadow of Chernobyl, with the addition of a few new ones. The swamps and red forest are the highlights, creating a fresh change from gloomy landscapes to lush vegetation. Also, some of the reoccurring maps have been slightly altered to appear more lifelike. Remember, this takes place before the events of SoC. All in all, i think this game gets a bad rap. What it is missing from other stalker games it makes up for by introducing some iconic stalker features, like the upgrades. Again, mods are a-plenty here, but do yourself a favor and play vanilla first...on MASTER difficulty. It's brutal again, and the difficulty spike is worse this time around in the end, so be even more prepared. While it still may not be every stalker fan's cup of tea, it's still part of the stalker lore that every fan should check out. It's my personal favorite of the 3 games, mostly for the reasons of the pacing and balance. Difficult as hell, borderline rage-inducing in the end, but still worthwhile. Crowning achievement completing this on master. Good luck stalker.9.2/10

												Lots of good reviews on this game already so no need for me to spill much ink on the vanilla game.  Shortly i consider this the weakest game in the series - yet it's still head over shoulders better than many other more known FPS games. It's gritty world is unique and i have always had fond memories of this game series  (minus the endings for Clear Sky and Pripyat)... But no more on that.So why do i play this? I play this because of TFW mod (The Faction Wars) - Few know about this awesome mod that gives you a ton of gameplay by removing the story and remaking the world to support factions. It's a free world now yet the area is so familar. In this mod you start out as a loner without any equipment and it's up to you to try to survive. You'll need to eat, sleep and get paid. but that can be hard as there are no freebies in this game contrary to vanilla game. stashes are looted. corpses get looted right after the fighting stops and if you try to grab stuff that someone thinks belong to them they will confront you. Needless to say early game is hard but VERY rewarding. Later you will start doing faction missions - or continue to be a loner. It doesn't matter much what you choose. Point is the options are endless and there are so many routes to choose and before you know it the most limiting factor is your actual free time to play the game. I am looking forward to 50 hours+ of quality game time from this mod alone that executes just right the way faction wars should be.  Here is a good place to start looking at mods that might tickle you the right way: http://cheeki.violates.me/

content:
r 9, 2014
												This review is for people who have played Shadow of Chernobyl.  It's about the single-player campaign, with the Complete mod.  I hope you liked the previous game, because you're essentially about to play it again.  Given that this one is a prequel, there are so many similarities in the environment (which is about 80% the same as the first) that you get a kind of wistful echo of adventures past (or rather, future).  It's a bit interesting to see what various parts of the zone were like before SoC.  You play as Scar, a merc who has survived emissions from the Zone for some unknown reason.  Once again you're chasing Strelok (really!?!).  The first time he entered the heart of the zone it set off an emission which was similar to a small cataclysm, setting all the factions against each other.  Your objective is to prevent him from doing it again, which would possibly produce a lethal emission killing everyone.  The new wrinkle this time is the faction system.  It's really just an extension of the old system, with some capture the flag type elements.  You can even take part in the initial war between Duty and Freedom this time around if you like.  Although the rewards are meager for this type of activity, it nonetheless makes the zone a far more dynamic place than it used to be, with NPC's shifting around constantly depending on who wins what fights.  Inconsequential, but you do get this vague sense that you have a hand in shaping the zone.  The combat system is still bull****.  I hope you weren't expecting any serious improvements.  Bullets still go wherever the **** they want, even with the Dragunov on occasion.  Enemy AI is just as bad, possibly a little worse (and that's with a patch to improve it!).  Even so, it is definitely satisfying getting the headshots with a scoped weapon.  This time around you can actually upgrade your weapons at various smiths, and find schematics to deliver to the appropriate npcs in order to get specific upgrades.  Kinda neat, and meant to extend the life of the game, but wholly unnecessary.  Same goes for your typical stash drops, which are now a part of NPC dialogues.  Fork over some dough for the information, and most of the time they'll tell you what's in it before you even leave camp.  You'll still reload frequently, but nowhere near as much or nearly as rage-inducing as the first game.  I can't testify as to how bad the final mission is (remember the last one on SoC?).  My game permanently crashed on all saves about two areas before the end, so I had to watch the ending on Youtube.  It was moderately unsatisfactory, and frankly I'm glad that I didn't have to worry about however bad the last mission was probably going to be.  A lot of other stuff is recycled.  The game looks a little better, but you can tell they didn't particularly try.  If you look at my play-time, I'm guessing it's about the same length as the first, maybe even a little shorter.  The shelf life was no doubt meant to be extended via multiplayer and dynamic zone faction wars.  This is Shadow of Chernobyl 1.5, essentially.  How much you liked the first game will directly determine if you like the second.

Although reguarded as the worst of the three, I still think it is a must play.  The beginning is slow and the ending is unfairly hard, with the everything in the middle being one of the most unique out of the three. Faction wars brings a whole new mechanic to the table. As long as you don't finish them completely off, one of the most immersive to me.  There are a few bugs in the game, and after finishing the vanilla game I played it with the STALKER Complete Mod.  This to me is a bugfix and not really a mod, since it really keeps the immersion of the vanilla game.=Open world atmospheric thriller =Side  quests and pda function more appropriately=Improved map and Pda=Weather is superbThe big downsdie to Clear Sky is the ending.  Yes there is a point of no return and if you are not prepared you may not be able to beat it. It is hard, ruthless and unforgiving.  Depending on your point of view you may be disappointed with the ending as well.  But in this game, its the journey, not exactly the ending that is memorable.Still a 9.9/10, and a must play.

content:
er 23, 2014
												The second game in the series, but the first chronologically (being a prequel), this game is by far the most underrated of the series. 9/10, if you ask a S.T.A.L.K.E.R's least favorite game in the series... it's this one, it gets a lot of hate for the fact that on release it was very unoptimized and buggy and there really wasn't any workaround for it. But now, of course, like any other game in the series, a ton of mods are available for us to choose from and almost all of them include bug fixes and optimization features. Some of them stop there, upgrading the graphics a little, optimizing the game for you, and fixing common bugs and issues. Others, however, expand on the open faction system that this prequel provides. Unlike in Shadow of Chernobyl, this game allows you to interact openly and work with the factions outside of their main quest lines, going as far as joining them after reaching a certain status; and that's not just Duty and Freedom, that's almost any faction in the game.The story, while not expanding too much on the events its predecessor, provide a little insight into what was going on in Shadow of Chernobyl and why it was happening, as well as revealing to you (Scar) information that Strelok did not know at the time. Don't get me wrong, Strelok is a cool guy, but Scar is probably my favorite character of the series. Either way, don't ignore this game because of earlier setbacks and whatnot, with the mods you have available now you can experience the game in almost a completely vanilla state (if you so wish) with all of the bugs and unoptimized mess fixed and cleaned up.Again, an excellent series; the story, atmosphere, characters, and mod variety all make it worth its price. Tons of replayability to be had.

While this one was a big disappointment for many people, but there's no reason what so ever that this is not hell right worth the sweet $9.9 dollars.Gameplay+ Fast-travel is now available.+ Atmosphere is spot-on, from the start.+ Overall map and mini-map are improved.+ In term's of weapon's it feel's less twicthy.+ Over 4 factions to choose from,all with pretty rewards.+ Weapon's and armor have been made upgradable now.+ Many more realism improvements add a good challenge.+ Artifect's can't be found laying around now, you have to put more effort.- Side-quests are mostly meh.- Bugs,bugs and bugs ranging from A.i to crashes and more.- Many armors and some weapons have been made inaccessible.- Faction-war's are broken, many of the time's the squad or the enemies may not even arrive.- Gun`s at times feel like you are using a toy gun,this is the case with many of them weapons.Story+ It isn't so worse, pretty fine in my opinion that is.+ It's well-placed, many scary and tide turning moments.+ Voice-acting has improved and is best from the all the-three.- Disappointing ending.- It may seem pretty confusing for starters.- Dialogue actually seems a bit odd at times.- Many scripted moments where you don`t have much a choice.Graphic's+ They sure have been improved from lighting to the texture's.+ Model's are more better looking and npc clothing has been made more-cooler.- Many micro-stutter's in between.- Buggy and just plain bad animations.- At time's the graphic's really show there age, from poorly textured wall's and bar's.- Optimazation is a pretty bad factor here, many even high-end machine's may not be able to run at decent (high) setting's.Design+ Just pure feeling of bitterness.+ Many previous areas have been improved.- Generic map design and corridors as the game progresses.Sounds+Ost+ Ost gets the job done with it's bitterness.+ Voice-acting has improved and is best from all the-three.+ Overall sounds i think are really generally better from nature to weapons.- Same reused menu-music.------------------------------------------------------------------------Transactions and cut-scenes are nothing special and quite boring on the part, as well the whole game it feels as a chore as you are just being used and throwed around by literally everyone.ConclusionIn all even though the countless amounts of bugs and roughness id say really get it if you havent played any of the s.t.a.l.k.e.r games then this one is more good for starters.===================================================================Click me and follow us as Curator

content:
3, 2016
												Note: This review is for the vanilla Stalker Clear Sky.Stalker Clear Sky is the prequel entry to the series, the game has you play as a Merc named Scar, who survives a large emission storm and is trying to find Strelok before he reaches the center of the zone. Stalker Clear Sky is a hit and miss for many fans of the series as it introduces some great ideas and makes some questionable decisions. While many consider the intro segment an example of the games flaws, I did not find myself dying that much but I can see why players dislike Clear Sky. The intro segment in the swamps is unlike any Stalker game as it has the player in a specific area, running errands, and doing very little exploring. Getting into gunfights more frequently and constantly finding myself against large enemy groups with a double barrel was kinda ridiculous. There are also a lot of questionable decisions which would leave new players to the series baffled as the first entry route to Cordon will have a player against an army base and the player was suppose to know to take a different path in. Minor decisions like that are what makes Clear Sky a fustrating experience. Another horrible decision was to make bandages rare as heck and needing mutiple amounts of them to plug up one injury. Clear Sky does however bring the faction system and uses it fairly well. Players are encouraged to join factions to gain access to better gear and is a core aspect of the game. The PDA is better in Clear Sky compared to SoC. Clear Sky however performs the worst of all Stalker games as I had constant crashes and error messages in my playthrough. Interesting to note is that Clear Sky looks the best of all vanilla Stalker games as it has some impressive dynamic lighting, great amount of vegetation on screen with an impressive draw distance. Pros:- The new faction system is a good idea and used well.- Weapons can be upgraded and modified.- Large amount of Hub worlds compared to the other Stalkers.- Many factions exist to make the faction system useful.- The FoV effect/motion blur when reloading and moving looks amazing.- Visually impressive for a near decade old game.- Great to revisit areas before the events of the first game.- Gunplay is tight and requires players to play slow.Cons:- No hunger system, this makes food an alternative to medical kits which makes no sense whatsoever.- Bandages and Anti rad became rare which can create very fustrating moments of dying slowly.- The worst intro segment in any Stalker game and maybe difficult enough to make players quit out right.- Auto save is poor so spam that F5 key.- The akward natural difficulty curve of the game may throw off players.- Crash city and error messages galore.- Bugs.- While the gunplay is tight, pistols cannot have aim down sights...- Ai has the habit in the starting sequence of turning shotguns into sniper rifles while you cannot do the same (get some slugs).- No tutorial so please new comers do not get this game first.Clear Sky isn't the worst game I have played and is enjoyable at times. However, the many questionable decisions that Clear Sky made in its game can make it a test of patience and sometime push it a little too far. Clear Sky does get easier as the player progresses and while Clear sky does not differ to much from SoC, SoC executed its concepts/mechanics correctly. SoC may have a difficult beginning segment also, but the way SoC handled healing items and made the difficulty scale naturally was great. Certain areas in SoC were loaded with harder enemies so you came back when you had the gear to go toe to toe with them. Clear Sky throws military units armed with AKs or Akabans whIle you just managed to leave the beg inning hub world. Clear Sky has some idea of what SoC was trying to do but is recommended for the veteran Stalker player. If your new to the series, start with SoC or heck even CoP, but save Clear Sky for last cause it will smack you around.

content:
22, 2016
												   My recorded playtime is not reflective of actual playtime. I've bought Clear Sky twice now, and I play a modded version now.    So first, I'll give a review of the game by itself, then add a little something for the vets.This is a great tactical fps and rpg game. The gun mechanics feel so good in this game. It's not like most games where bullet spread and accuracy is just enough enough of a factor to notice it in game. Here you you really have to have good aim, and you have to stabilize your gun before you fire. Getting into a battle with a couple bandits with a shotgun in this game feels more epic and real than anything you'll see in a COD or Battlefield or just about any other shooter. The AI is just awesome. Taking cover, blind fire, flanking, retreating, grenades, camping, even sneaking on a rare occasion. The combat mechanics are my favorite part of this game; every gun feels different and realistic, and every encounter gets the adrenalin going.    The art is another thing, some people find the game ugly, but I think it's got the best sun rays and dynamic effects I've ever seen. They had volumetric fog in this around the same time as the AAA games started getting it. There is nothing like the zone though, I find myself screenshotting a lot in this game. Seeing water stream down walls and the sunrays through trees or windows... it's just a beautiful game.     The story is great too, but it is mostly an addition to the story of Call of Chernobyl. That game had a bit of a better story with the whole "Kill Strelok" mission, but this one simply adds to that. What this story does better than the other STALKER games, and heres where I start talking to the vets, is it takes you through the areas of the zone at a much more balanced and compelling pace. It kinda funnels you through these scenarios that slowly feel more and more epic, because of the gameplay challenges presented.      Now with all that said, I think this is the best of the STALKER games, and I think it's worthy to note that it is cheaper than the others last I saw. Of course they all have their own merits and flaws but I like the mechanics the best in this one, and the challenge. I also believe that it has the best mods available for it, there's a few that combine it with the first stalker which is just perfect I think.

content:
1, 2016
												Heard about this game from youtube. Did some research, and bought it on sale in steam. Before I played, I donned the traditional gopnik flat cap and slav squatted for the whole game. I played this game with NO fixes. NO mods. Master difficulty. You drop into the game with a little cinematic, and it looks... EEEEH. You spawn in and these random science gopniks tell you "you should be dead but you're not so get gun and go in swamp ♥♥♥♥♥."At this point I had no idea what was going on, so I got my gun, and headed into swamp. Instantly, I noticed my main gun had 30 rounds of ammo, and this sets precedent for the entire game. You have NO AMMO. And, to make things worse, all the guns are peashooters that, even with a 1.6x scope, you can't hit a dinner plate from 10 yards.So the thing that made this game unique was it's AI system and environment. The AI is so cool, fighting it out even when you aren't there. securing the swamp for the science gopniks was easy because they did all the work for me. But as soon as I thought AYYY this isn't as hard as people say, I made it out of the swamp and went to the cordon. This game does not hold your hand. it doesn't tell you "go north to avoid the gun" it says "FIGURE IT OUT YOURSELF ♥♥♥♥♥" as I went north, I encountered a squad of Renegades. All I had was a hunting rifle, which is GARBAGE at ranges, and one of them had a Viper 5. It took me 30 minutes to defeat them. this is where you get introduced to your good friends f5 and f9.F5 quicksaves. You should do this A TON. The game never autosaves, and added onto the difficulty, this can be hell. But if you get past that one squad that you've been fighting after 15 minutes, the feeling is SO GREAT. Skipping ahead, I had arrived at Agroprom, and I joined duty and beat freedom. After that, I headed to the place that enters the Red Forest. that's where the atmosphere really hit me. It's so good looking and fits perfectly. For all this complaining I cannot reccomend this game enough. The game is hard, but it rarely is unfair.EDIT: After thinking the review over, I am changing my review to an 8/10. This game has some flaws. I haven't tried SOC, but with this game, my hopes could not be higher.

content:
14, 2015
												Stalker Shadow of Chernobyl (SoC) is one of my all-time favourite games I have played thus far – even made it as one of my top ten of all times. Blends with FPS, survival and a touch of role playing elements, it was brutal, yet enjoyable experience. So when I hear that the next Stalker game was on the horizon (instead of waiting for seven years), I couldn’t wait to see what GSC Game World have in store. Well, just a year later, along arrives Stalker, Clear Sky (CS) – a prequel to SoC and sadly, also a lessor game in most areas as the new features like Faction Wars just didn’t pan out effectively.Like most open world games, it’s hard to say how long to beat it. For me, as I like to do literally everything and explore every nook and cranny, took me about 65 hours to complete, so I can safely assume average will be around 20 or so. Pretty decent with a good array of missions / side quests and diversions, CS is unfortunately a step down from SoC. The new features like Faction Wars and able to customise your weapons did not pan out well enough as actually, they are more of a hindrance or simply, not worth investing your time. However the emission blowout was pretty awesome due to its sudden nature. So if you are coming from SoC, expect to be disappointed however if this is your first Stalker game, it’s an enjoyable ride but expect spoilers. I guess you can view CS as a rock and a hard place.Full review here: http://www.gamespot.com/s-t-a-l-k-e-r-clear-sky/user-reviews/2200-12643375/7.5 / 10

er 5, 2015
												The atmosphere is great, as in any STALKER game, and things are up to the level of SoC and CoP for a while.Until you decide to get involved in the faction wars (extremely bugged) or until you reach the last 25% of the story: then it's just a military shooter, where enemies will home their granades right between your eyes. Tons and tons of human enemies to kill, but the atmosphere is completely lost.What made SoC and CoP great games was slowly passing though abandoned towns and desolated landscapes, looking for precious artifacts and watching your back from bloodsuckers and other mutants. If you want this in CS, you need to really force it upon the game.On top of that, mind that most (all?) maps and locations are the same of SoC. I played SoC some 4/5 years ago and still got lots of deja vu. It can be nice, realising that you actually know this or that place, but feels a bit lazy somehow.Overall, I recommend it to STALKER veterans who want a challenge, but perhaps CoP with mods is a better choice. In any case, do not forget to install the Sky Reclaimation Project to fix bugs and enhance the experience.If you have never played a STALKER game, play Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Prypjat first. Those are the real deal.

												Ever since a young age I have been playing the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series and to this day I play and love each of the three games. I've completed them all countless times and still enjoy the fantastic moody and eerie atmosphere. It's open-world and features and inventory with equippable weapons and protective suits all of which are upgradable and have conditions which must be repaired. The best way I could describe this game is like a Ukrainian twist on the Fallout games. The story isn't fantastic, voice acting is minimal and the game isn't a refined masterpiece but every gameplay element makes up for it from searching for rare artifacts to helping your faction in faction wars. The world is large and full of action and exploration in each part. With the amount of hours I've spent in this game both on steam and the retail copy I owned, I feel that it's worth every penny I spent.

The second part of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series: "Clear Sky" The prehistory of "Shadow of Chernobyl"...You are playing the mercenary "Scar" (german: Narbe). Once you were outside when a big anomaly explosion happens, you survived in a mysterious way, you were found by the leader of the Clear Sky faction Lebedew. He declared you, why the anomalies have to stop (else you would also die, so you have no choice).You find out that, a guy named Strelok made it behind the "brain smelter" - this is the reason, why those anomalies happen.I have to stop now, I don't want to spoil you :-)You are going through known areas like: the red forest, the dump and the Kordon. You also see other and new places like: the hospital, the swamp and the city Limansk.++ it's still a S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game++ you can drink also here vodka++ map design is beautiful and huge++ fast travel!! (but it costs)++ not a bit less in atmosphere+ the sounds are ok (better in the first part)+ improved voice-acting+ improved graphics+ the night... is dark. Not like in the first part+ more weapons (...don't say that they are better)+ really challenging sometimes (also on normal)+ you can fight for your faction and have to defend your facilities against your enemies and even mutantsbut, I have to say...- these faction or defending tasks get really fast irritating and boring- the KI has sometimes the IQ of a toast... a wet toast- loads of bugs, so make more than 2 save games- the story is a little bit... incomprehensible- "only" one end. First part had 7 endings."Clear Sky" is a worthy successor of "Shadow of Chernobyl" - but, the negatives aspects like the end, the bugs or the comparison to the first part... makes me to give "Clear Sky" only 7/10. But it is still a good and nice game! :-)

 S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky  Clear Sky is a good game however has a lot of shortcomings in optimization. The game can drag on for many hours of fun by performing the side missions. This part is no different practically nothing as the previous one but there are plenty of new stuff. The game has been improved graphically however it is not well optimized. Night are darker and even we have access to fast traveling of course for a price. We will also visit the new areas of Zona such as swamps or Limansk however in this part there is no Pripyat :(. Weapons and suits are the same however we are able join to different factions such as the Freedom, Duty, Clear Sky, bandits or stalkers. Soundtrack irritated me because it was too dynamic but after few hours i got used to this. The main character of the game is nameless mercenary working for the Clear Sky faction and our task is to prevent disaster. The game is certainly good and above all it is not until such a way to buy especially in some pack from humble bundle or on the other site.

												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is a great post-apocalytpic game. It has an amazingly large world, full of mutants, and characters, and radiation, and whatever you can think of in a post-apocalyptic game. It has a great atmosphere that makes you feel like you're actually in the post-apocalyptic time period, and I recommend it. This game can be a little annoying sometimes, because of how challenging the combat is, and how hard it is to afford new weapons and supplies, but that only adds to the realism and atmosphere of a post-apocalyptic game. People say it's the worst out of the series, and if it is, the rest of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games must be amazing. It has a photo realistic world, and it's very fun to explore it. If you have ten dollars, you should definitely get this game.

												Many people consider this to be the worst of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R franchise, but I honestly love this game more than the other two. It may be because this was the first one I played, but i always found it to be great compared to the two because of the faction wars, the hunting of artifacts, the areas, and the story. Don't get me wrong, the other games were amazing in some of these fields, but clear sky really gave me the feeling of being in a crazy place while being invested in the story and places I went. I did encounter a bug which forced me to play the entire game all over again (thanks lefty) but it allowed me to redo my work and actually get more than what I had before. Aside from that bug, I've had a rather smooth playthrough compared to what other people have experienced. I don't know if these were anomalies (bad joke) from the rest of the crowd, but be wary of the chance anything could happen and constantly save and have your backups. This game isn't perfect, but i guess the bias I have for it being my first S.T.A.L.K.E.R  makes it shine from the rest. Give it a try, you probably won't regret it!

content:
ry 28
												An amazing game that was, and somewhat still is, grossly overlooked due to its seemingly older graphics (X-Ray 1.5 engine). However the gameplay and atmosphere more than make up for it. This game was, and still is, simply brilliant! The entire S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-series is one awesome ride!^^^ POSSIBLE SPOILER WARNING ^^^Not sure what exactly pet peeved some people into disliking this particular one in the trilogy, but I believe that of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise, this is an amazing ´sequel´ to the Shadow of Chernobyl.I use the term losely in this concept, as Clear Sky takes place prior to the events of SoC, yet is the 2nd installment in the trilogy (red.)CS brings in the familiar tone and setting from the SoC and along with it, a shít-ton of new features (and bugs).Right off the bat; this game is not perfect, however it is damn near perfection when modded properly for more realistic lighting, shadow, texture and sounds - however I suggest newcomers to experience the vanilla game beforehand.The story - which can be read/summerised in the wiki-page - is nothing unusual. In fact, SoC had somewhat of a more interesting angle to the protagonist than CS. Nonetheless, it´s still manages to draw you in.As someone who´s obsessed with snipers, CS offers a even larger variety in the gamplay, with the added feature of modding your weapons! From a simple reduction in recoil of your guns, to more accuracy and flatness (projectile speed) and undermounted grenade launcher, you can customize almost any given weapon to fit your needs/style. Add the choice to attack a scope to nearly any rifle, you can turn a full automatic AK into a mid-range sniper rifle. Granted, I wouldn´t go with an AK due to their terribly low accuracy, but just as an example.NOTE! Most first tier modifications are available at nearly any weapon smith. To unlock the 2nd and last tier, you´ll need the blueprints/schiematics in form of USB-drives (that´s right, bítches, it´s USB sticks).These can be obtained from loot spots (backpacks, boxes, supplies or others), which you can learn about from either PDAs on enemies or buying the info from bartenders or other NPCs.Another option is doing missions - main or side, they will reward you occasionally with a USB, unlocking mod possibilities for various weapons - and even armor!Artifacts, bítches! Get em while they´re hot!The enemies vary from a simple bandit in Addidas track suit, taking pot shots at you with a 9mm well beyond it´s accuracy threshold, to SVD Dragunov wielding bullet sponges in exoskeletal armor to psy-enhances mutants, with the power to debilitate and kill even the most hardened veteran of the Zone, should you be unlucky enough.NOTE! I found shotguns to be particularly useful at point blank when dealing with almost any mutants. Thanks to the spread, it made zig-zag´ing dogs and bloodsuckers(!) easier to deal with. Bloodsuckers are even tougher than in SoC. At least in my experience. They seem to be circling around you in an effort to distract and avoid gunfire more frequently than the SoC-variations.The factions and their disputes are on much larger scale than SoC, meaning you´ll have plenty of oppertunities to either push or prevent a certain faction to advance or retreat. Ultimately you can wipe out entire factions, should you be so bold. (still not certain if it was intended as an option in the game or not. Could be part of a mod. Might edit if any news should present itself)The locations are almost identical to the SoC with a few improvements and changes in the direction of progress. Still that eerie and gloomy tone and ambience to really make it more fun plaing all alone in complete darkness. It´s called immersion, I´m told.Conclusion: Outstanding game which deserves every praise and attention it gets!

content:
r 29, 2016
												Clear Sky is an entertaining game that expands on Shadow of Chernobyl (SoC).The story, atmosphere, and sounds are still on point. I found it strange that you end up fighting humans a lot more than dungeon crawling and fighting mind-controlling mutants in this game. This game also introduces a faction war system, which is pretty cool. It gives me more people to shoot at with my ultra-high accuracy rifle.If you're bothered by the wacky, inaccurate aiming system, I suggest you use the hunting rifle until you get a more accurate weapon. You can steal an AC-96 from the military people (South Cordon) and upgrade it (with scope and silencer). Then, use that until you get an F-200M and upgrade that. Also, always aim for the head. 1-3 hits will always kill.If you need money, sell medical gear, weapons, and artifacts. Artifacts are hard to come by so keep the great ones for yourself. Always be on the lookout for anomalies, pull out your detector (press O) and look for them.This game is hard as hell. You'll be pressing F5 and F9 a lot. But, if you stick with it, you'll be able to get the best equipment in the game and end up... pressing F5/ F9 less often.Also, that incessant buzzing noise from using Night Vision for hours on end is stuck in my brain. It's like a brain scorcher.End game Gear:Weapon: FT200 (upgraded for accuracy) with some worthless pistolArmor: CS-1 (Upgraded for armor and night vision)Detector: VelesArtifacts: Bubble, and the artifacts that give you more endurance and less weight.Faction: FreedomCheeki Breeki

												While definitely not as good as SoC, i dont think its a waste of time like anyone says.The athmosphere is really really good, just like in the previous one. I find the weapons to be more realistic and better, while the enemies were also a really big challenge. The addition of faction wars is quite nice, and also the new way of finding artifacts and dealing with anomalies. The graphics, while not the best, definitely improved, as well as some in-game aspects like the HUD, the radar etc. Another thing i really really liked was the addition of new areas on the map, which werent there in the previous game-they made this experience feel refreshing. Sad part is there arent some other areas anymore, like Prypiat and Rostok. I'd say the worst part of this game would be the side quests. Those are kinda bad and dont give rewards worth fighting for, tho i do recommend doing some in order to have better equipment (i dont even know how i managed to finish the game with no body armour, no bandages and only a few medkits-i guess i got lucky). Just like SoC, Clear Sky also has strong replayability Overall, I strongly recommend this game to everyone, especially those who played the first one, for it is challenging and fun (SoC is still better though)Stay cheeki breeki

er 27, 2013
												You know, for a Prologue, It is not bad. It could have been better though.The Gameplay, levels, and Characters are still here. They are just worn down slightly. But the difficulty curve goes to the highest level at the beginning, and gets much harder over time. You cannot survive more than a Couple Makarov bullets ripping through your flesh, but all the other enemies can survive so many rounds to the point that you are wasting your own ammo. Money is much harder to make, Medical supplies are impossible to find, but Ammo is so easy to find. The story is slowly paced but very well performed and well written. AI is a mixed bag, Artifacts now require a detector to find, But this and all the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R entries are beautifully designed, immersive, and can be replayed over and over again. I am glad this is $10 less tthan the other two because It is quite weaker actually. But I think this is better than Call of Pripyat. THATS RIGHT.  This game hits more notes than CoP. Might as well play this after you complete SHoC.Overall: 7.9/10

content:
er 23, 2015
												Stalker has been considered by many a post-apocalyptic first person shooter game. But it isn't, your in a Cordon zone of the Chernobyl area that has been abandon since April of 1986 due to NPP4 catastrophic failure rendering the environment hazardous to live in. Yes, the place dose exists for real, all locations are based on real locations in the real zone. Life is still going on everyday for the people out side of the zone. The Stalker game series is inspired off the book "Roadside Picnic", which is a short science fiction novel written by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky in 1971. More information on this book is available on a wiki, and the book is also available in English now.  The game is a open world exploration as well as mission directive, Remember that.Clear Sky has its bugs elements but I like the game and has been fun, I been in the zone here since the first release of the dvd of the 1.0 version.  Here your in the Cordon off Zone in which has become a prison. You can get in, but you can't get out. There is trading with traders, and different factions that may or may not care for you. Many dangerous anomalies to contend with, and artifact to collect and sell for money. Have to watch out for the areas that are radioactive still. One of the things to remember is question everyone and trust no one. Being skeptical with a gut feeling at times is better than a fire fight, When in this game it is important.The annoying draw back in this game is the bug issues, for some reason even a updated version of the game on steam has not cleared bug issues that rolled over from the 1.0 of the game. For this game, mainly if you plan to use a mod, you really need to have at lest 4gigs of ram for the best results. It works on win7 64 bit, but there has been complaints pending Operating systems causing issues with the game. You may want to check in the forums. Due to the buggy issues I normally would not recommend the game, but Others had been able to play the default game and complete it. And the stalker community out of many I have seen is the most helpful there. It seems every stalker dose what they can to help you. And a good community like that is a nice thing to have.  Makes it hard not to recommend the game.

												Personally i believe this is one of the best games ever due to how dynamic the gameplay is. If your into first person or any open world shooter this is the game for you. Not only is clear sky good but they have other games in the series such as shadow of Chernobyl or call of pripyat. The stalker series would of been amazing if they haven't of given up on the stalker 2 game but they did and now the licence was grabbed my bit composer, which is making the game survarium a look alike to the stalker series turned into a first person mmo shooter. Over all of this game i have to give it a 10/10. i don't want to be a graphic's ♥♥♥♥♥ but the game was made a while back so don't expect far cry or skyrim graphics. Now i'm going to go into the dynamics part of the game. The game is very immersive. you can spend around 1-5 hours on this game and get back to the real world like "What just happened?" In this game in the series (Clear Sky) you play as a mercenary named scar. you were able to survive a emission which is a blast of radioactive energy that kills anything that is stupid enough to get caught in one. during this game you will encounter mutants, bandits, and anomalies. Mutants have very nice models; The Pseudo dogs for example, they have very nice facial features witch can really be frightening at the night time play through's. The Players in this game don't have the best AI as they might hide behind something that is not as much "cover" and they will shout obscenity's at you in Russian as you fight them. This is the only game were i believe the bandits don't kill you on site, unlike on shadow of Chernobyl were they just are marked as enemy.If you buy this game, don't. just save for the bundled pack of the stalker series because during a sale, like the winter sales event you would be able to pick it up for 15 bucks, as did I. The game is GREAT! if you know anyone that is into lore as skryim you can get into the lore in stalker. it may be dark and a bit freaky but it will amaze you in the lifestyles and hardships that they face every day.***** Five stars, Buy this game!oh, it also has a terrible multiplayer.... but who cares right?

content:
1, 2012
												Clear Sky is another fine entry in the STALKER series. Less intense than Shadow of Chernobyl (SOC); less claustrophobic, less scary. But all the incredible atmosphere of this genre-bending series is intact. Impressively, compared to SOC, Clear Sky presents both a more linear main quest, and a more sandboxy world to explore.There are some bugs in this game. The map for the city of Limansk... some people can't load games that are saved on this map, which makes it very difficult to complete the game. Because of the bugs, many people skip this title and move straight to Call of Pripyat.To beat Limansk, I used the "Wish Granter” feature that is included in the Stalker Complete mods to spawn myself some allies to help me through Limansk without saving. (More on the "Complete" mods in the comments below). The STALKER series is one of PC gaming's finest. If you miss the complexity and subtlety that we used to enjoy before consoles got popular, you really should check these games out.

content:
0, 2015
												Personal review of: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear SkyMods: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky CompleteDifficulty: MasterS.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky is a sequel/prequel to the events prior to Shadow of Chernobyl. Taking place in 2011, where a second emission took place and created the Zone, a place filled with mutants, strange anomalies, and it's populated by STALKERS, basically scavengers/fighters/artifact seekers, you get the point. You play as Scar, a veteran STALKER chasing down Strelok when an emission hits and you are left incapacitated. You wake up at Clear Sky base, a swamp base where this faction is devoted to understanding the Zone and learning all it's secrets and uncovering the strange phenomens going on. After you finish a few tasks you are free to explore the Zone and side with whatever faction you want, explore and play the game. I won't say more than this since it took me 2,5 hours just to leave the Swamp areas (doing quests, exploring etc.), so the rest is up to you to find out. The game is built on the same X-Ray engine, with a few updated changes. Mainly the AI has been tweeked to fit the new faction war system, visuals have been upped, and many more changes have been implemented. As far as Stalker Clear Sky goes, almost all the weapons have been reused for this prequel, half of the areas too meaning you will revisit some familiar places while exploring new ones. Enemies, NPC's too, so you might find the actual content of this one a bit lacking. Onto more relevant changes, the HUD got reworked, being simplified, also the PDA got some new features, being able to track more easily your tasks, you can now see enemy/friendly factions on the radar, giving you a better understading of where they are being concentrated, etc. The hunger system has been removed, don't know why honestly, weapon upgrades are available, the way you collect/obtain artifacts has also been changed, to the point where you need to use an artifact detector to "see" them. This also implies you will have to walk into the middle of anomalies and hope you won't get killed before you collect them. Stalker Clear Sky has received some flak, being the "weakest" part of the trilogy, and I can see why. This game really kicks you in the balls, same as Shadow of Chernobyl, you start off really underpowered, with little to no ammo/supplies to push through the onslaught of enemies in the Swamp areas. Beware, playing this game and rushing the main storyline will result in a frustratingly hard game. I recommend taking your time and exploring, doing side-quests, parting with different factions as it will result in a much more relaxed experience. It's hard as ♥♥♥♥. There's no doubt about it. But why is it hard? All Stalker games are hard, there's no question about it, this is how these games were built, as an PC exclusive hardcore survival/rpg-ish experience, but S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky comes short in some areas. The thing is the atmosphere, lighting, texture quality is on par and beyond it's first game, but it falls flat in AI behaviour, there are less underground areas to explore (which were a highlight), side tasks include a lot of fetching and killing. These are the most basic things about it. Then we move into combat, wich remains largely unchanged except for one thing. Grenades, I can't stres enough how annoying this addition is, not only will NPC's hit you 90% with them, they will also result in an instant death on higher difficutly levels, which is not very Stalker like. We all know how you can't really take cover in these games, being surrounded by anomalies, high radiation levels and NPC's throwing grenades makes the combat feel unfair at times. Also the fact that they still use the same weapons as you use, only with 100% accuracy and 0 bullet drop is just horse ♥♥♥♥. Seriously. My main gripe with this game is the combat. It feels so random and so luck based that it's the single thing that really kills this game. Don't get me wrong, this is a massive game, with tons of stuf to do, but when it comes to combat (being an FPS game also) it sucks. It just ♥♥♥♥ing sucks. Bullets dance around hitboxes all the time, it feels like when you shoot in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky you play roullete or you roll the dice. It all comes down to what the game wants to hit, not you. Fully upgraded weapons feel the same, so there's no excuse here. Secondly, the last part of the game (Once you reach Limansk) is just A grade bullcrap. This whole area is designed around enemies placed in hard to reach/predict areas, Monolith soldiers are so buffed, I died almost 50 times in the last part of the game alone. Seriously, a fully upgraded suit will only serve to protect you against 2-3 bullets maximum. There are also a lot of engine crashes here and plenty of bugs, so expect to be disappointed near the end of the game. And now, we have to move to the Chernobyl NPP area. SPOILER ALERT Once you reach Chernobly, this is where the game was at it's worst. First off, there are so many enemies at once, it's likely you will die 90% of the time without any chance of shooting back. Why? They never miss, they take 10-15 bullets to get killed. Also you're presured by the fac that you have to hit Strelok with a gun that isn't effective at all against all the Monolith soldiers being spawned  in this area. This last level is probably one of the worst I've ever played. No joke, hitscan enemies everywhere, almost 0 cover and little or no indication to what you're supposed to do or where Strelok is, I'm not asking for a ♥♥♥♥ing bullseye above his head, but seriously the minimap is useless here, and so are the teleporters, serving only to confuse the player. Want to know how ♥♥♥♥ this level is? It took me one hour to finish it, only because I died constantly and 70% of the time I was loading my last save game. When I did finish it, Strelok got stuck in an area off screen, seriously, he was outside Chernobyl and I was able to snipe him only to get the ending which only disappointed me. I played SoC and CoP and those game featured multiple endings, to my delight, here it's just the same 30 seconds cutscene, which I won't discuss for the sake of your own discovery. Anyways, let's cut the crap since this game is from 2008 and I've talked so much already nobody is going to bother reading this anyway, so here is a small list of what works and what doesn't in the 2nd Stalker instalmentThe good:Superb atmosphereAmazing lighting effectsAstounding weather changes + the seamless shifts from day-nightFaction warsWeapon customizationImproved HUD + PDA/Map systemRefined visuals, better draw distance and richer enviromentsHuge sandboxThe bad:Recycled enemies, weapons, enviroments make this Prequel feel like they used cut content/turned a boxed expansion pack into a standalone titleHorrible gun mechanics, play it for yourself I can't explain it (note: I didn't play the vanilla version, I can't imagine how bad the guns perform in the base game)The beginning and ending of this game are atrocious. HonestlyFewer underground areas, which were a highlight of this seriesThey removed the hunger system, the stamina system sucks in this, making it feel less survival compared to SoC and CoPLack of impact on the overall arch of the story, no matter what faction you chose, it all boils down to what gear you obtain, rendering the whole "choice" of it all utterly useless.Less russian dialogue and voiced lines, rendering the immersion to a bare minimum in this title.Little to non-existent expansion on the Stalker universe&lore.In the end, I can only recommend S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky only with Mods, I've tried it with Complete only, but I still recommend it, there are few games that come close to it. A personal rating of 7/10.

content:
9, 2015
												Universally considered the "worst" STALKER game out of the three, it is not necessarily a bad game. In short, if you like any other STALKER game you should give this a playthrough.This game lacks the bleakness and some of the atmosphere found mainly in Shadow of Chernobyl but also Call of Pripyat. The Zone is very populated by NPCs compared to other STALKER games which very much contributes to the fact that the environment feels less hostile. Compared to the 4 horror centric underground areas of SHoC, Clear Sky only has one that is less frightening compared to the SHoC counterparts. Compared to unmodded SHoC, Clear Sky is in many ways a bit more polished in terms of better animation quality, graphical effects and user interface. Clear Sky also introduces a much welcomed weapon upgrade/repair system that was absent from SHoC.While I generally think that the first time you play a STALKER game it should be unmodded I would say that I make an exception for Clear Sky. Clear Sky unmodded has some issues that are flat out annoying and I would consider it bare minimum to install the Sky Reclamation Project (latest version as of 2015-06-30 is 1.0.4) to fix most of those issues. SRP is still pretty close to a vanilla experience and is provided mainly to fix various bugs.I would also like to mention the following mods that doesn't impact gameplay but makes it look a bit better.Atmosfear 1.3 - Improves weather effects, improves game atmosphere (This is also available for Call of Pripyat)Absolute Nature/Structures - High resolution texture mods that makes things look a bit more crisp (This is also available for Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Pripyat)
